docs.snippet: Have you seen "The Red Shoes?" Please share your thoughts....
docs.lead_paragraph: In light of Natalie Portman's Oscar win this week for her role as an obsessive ballerina in "Black Swan," A. O. Scott looks back at "The Red Shoes," one of the definitive dance films about an artist who sacrifices herself for her art. The 1948 film, directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, is "a wonderful depiction of an artist at work and a fascinating examination of the obsessive drive to create art," Mr. Scott says. "But what makes it great is how completely it surrenders itself to that obsession."
docs.abstract: Have you seen "The Red Shoes?" Please share your thoughts.

docs.snippet: Tell us what "hidden talents" you think you might have, whether a skill you've never had the time to practice, an academic area you're particularly interested in or a sport or hobby you've never had the means to pursue but just know you'd love....
docs.lead_paragraph: We're inspired to ask this question today by this article, which describes how the Oscar winner Natalie Portman was also a semifinalist in the Intel science competition while in high school on Long Island - and then went on to study neuroscience at Harvard. Though, as the article points out, she is "depressingly impressive," everyone has talents he or she hasn't yet had the ability or drive to bring out. What do you think yours might be? Why? How do you think you could develop them?
docs.abstract: Tell us what "hidden talents" you think you might have, whether a skill you've never had the time to practice, an academic area you're particularly interested in or a sport or hobby you've never had the means to pursue but just know you'd love.

headline.main: What Hidden Talents Might You Have?

docs.snippet: DAINES--Richard F., MD. It is with a tremendous sense of sadness that the entire Continuum Health Partners community acknowledges the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague, Richard F. Daines, MD, former President of St. Luke...
docs.lead_paragraph: DAINES--Richard F., MD. It is with a tremendous sense of sadness that the entire Continuum Health Partners community acknowledges the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague, Richard F. Daines, MD, former President of St. Luke's and Roosevelt Hospitals (SLR) and former Commissioner of Health for New York State. Richard leaves behind a tremendous legacy of achievement in advancing healthcare delivery in New York State. As SLR President, Richard strengthened the hospital's clinical programs, broadened its primary care base, and put in motion expansion of emergency services at Roosevelt Hospital. He also developed and led very strong administrative and clinical management teams and cultivated a work environment that positively supported many of these successes. As State Health Commissioner, Richard took bold steps to appropriately adjust the size and scope of the State's health care delivery system. He also served as an advocate for improving the general health and well-being of all New Yorkers, advancing programs and initiatives that targeted our most pressing issues. And he brought back to the Department an environment of openness, collegiality and transparency. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Linda, his sons, William and Andrew, his daughter, Katherine, his parents, his siblings, a large extended family, many grateful patients and countless colleagues, friends and admirers. Richard will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO, Continuum Gail F. Donovan Executive Vice President and COO Continuum Frank J. Cracolici President, SLR Oscar Garfein, MD President, SLR Medical Board

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAINES, RICHARD F.

docs.snippet: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) ME FACING LIFE: CYNTOIA'S STORY In August 2004  Cyntoia Brown, 16, shot and killed Johnny Allen, a 43-year-old Tennessee real estate agent she said had picked her up for sex. Two years later Ms. Brown -- who had been bor...
docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) ME FACING LIFE: CYNTOIA'S STORY In August 2004 Cyntoia Brown, 16, shot and killed Johnny Allen, a 43-year-old Tennessee real estate agent she said had picked her up for sex. Two years later Ms. Brown -- who had been born to a 16-year-old and adopted as a toddler -- was tried as an adult, found guilty of first-degree murder and especially aggravated robbery, and sentenced to life. In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation, Daniel H. Birman follows Ms. Brown, above, for six years, starting the week she was arrested, in the hope of exposing the reasons for violence among youth. What he discovered was a history, seemingly shaped by heredity and circumstance, that had repeated itself through each generation of Ms. Brown's biological family. 5:30 P.M. (Cinemax) FUNNY PEOPLE (2009) In this film from Judd Apatow, Adam Sandler plays George Simmons, a stand-up comedian turned Hollywood star and jerk, who discovers that he has a rare, potentially fatal blood disease. Seth Rogen is Ira, the fledgling comic George hires as an assistant, who for the time being seems only too content to accept scraps from his employer. Mr. Apatow's wife, Leslie Mann, plays Laura, the love who got away from George, and the one he wants back now that he's dying. (The Apatows' daughters play Laura's children.) Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said there was ''something irritatingly self-satisfied'' about the film, partly stemming from the autobiographical touches. ''Watching 'Funny People,' you get the sense that Mr. Apatow, one of the most successful filmmakers working in Hollywood, is very happy,'' she wrote. ''Bummer.''
